definitions: Dark sarcomere band that contains the thick (myosin) filaments.
Region where myosin is present, including actin–myosin overlap.
Band whose length stays essentially constant during contraction.
Sarcomere zone associated with force production via crossbridges.
Neurotransmitter released by motor neurons at the neuromuscular junction.
Chemical that binds receptors on the motor end plate to initiate excitation.
Signal molecule that triggers depolarization of the muscle fiber membrane.
Messenger that converts a nerve impulse into a muscle action potential.
Primary protein of thin filaments in skeletal muscle.
Thin filament protein that interacts with myosin to generate force.
Filament anchored near the Z-line that slides during contraction.
Contractile protein whose binding sites are regulated by troponin/tropomyosin.
Rapid, self-propagating change in membrane voltage in excitable tissue.
Electrical signal formed by depolarization followed by repolarization.
All-or-none impulse that travels along an axon or sarcolemma.
Event triggered when membrane threshold is reached.
If threshold is reached, an action potential occurs fully; if not, it doesn’t occur.
A single muscle fiber contracts maximally once stimulated above threshold.
Principle applies to individual fibers/cells, not whole-muscle force output.
Explains why action potential amplitude is not graded with stimulus intensity.
Pressure of air within the alveoli.
Pressure changes that drive airflow during ventilation.
When below atmospheric pressure, air flows into the lungs.
Determines airflow direction along with atmospheric pressure.
Tiny lung air sacs where gas exchange occurs.
Terminal respiratory structures surrounded by pulmonary capillaries.
Site where O2 diffuses into blood and CO2 diffuses out.
High-surface-area units optimized for diffusion.
Semilunar valve between the left ventricle and the aorta.
Prevents backflow from the aorta into the left ventricle.
Opens during ventricular systole to allow ejection.
Closes during diastole to maintain one-way flow.
Bones of the limbs plus the pectoral and pelvic girdles.
Skeletal region responsible for movement of arms and legs.
Upper and lower extremities and their attachment structures.
Includes shoulder girdle, pelvis, and limb bones.
Vessels that carry blood away from the heart (arteries to arterioles).
High-pressure side of circulation delivering blood to tissues.
Distribution network routing cardiac output to capillary beds.
Arteries and arterioles that regulate delivery of blood to organs.
Small artery that regulates flow into capillaries via smooth muscle.
Primary site of vascular resistance and blood pressure control.
Vessel that vasoconstricts/vasodilates to control tissue perfusion.
Terminal arterial branch feeding capillary networks.
Blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart.
Thick-walled vessel built to handle higher pressures.
Typically carries oxygenated blood (except pulmonary arteries).
Elastic and muscular vessel that smooths pulsatile flow.
Conduction fibers that carry impulses from the AV node to the ventricles.
Electrical pathway connecting atrial and ventricular conduction systems.
Tract that splits into left and right bundle branches.
Key link for transmitting depolarization into ventricular myocardium.
Cardiac structure that delays and relays impulses from atria to ventricles.
Conduction “gate” that coordinates timing for ventricular filling.
Node that slows electrical transmission before ventricular activation.
Part of the conduction system between atria and ventricles.
Valves between atria and ventricles that prevent backflow during systole.
Mitral (left) and tricuspid (right) valves.
Close when ventricles contract to stop regurgitation into atria.
Ensure one-way flow from atria into ventricles.
Upper chamber of the heart that receives returning blood.
Right atrium receives systemic venous blood; left atrium receives pulmonary venous blood.
Heart chamber that fills ventricles through AV valves.
Preload chamber that contracts to assist ventricular filling.
Skull, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum.
Central skeleton that supports posture and protects organs.
Trunk and head bones forming the body’s core framework.
Skeletal components aligned along the body’s midline.
Joints permitting motion in two planes.
Examples include condyloid (MCP) and saddle joints.
Allow flexion/extension plus abduction/adduction.
Two-axis synovial joints enabling combined movements.
Tough connective tissue membrane covering outer bone (except articular surfaces).
Layer involved in bone growth, repair, and nutrient supply.
Attachment site for tendons/ligaments via Sharpey’s fibers.
Protective outer sheath rich in nerves and blood vessels.
Slower-than-normal heart rate (often <60 bpm in adults, context dependent).
Can be normal in trained endurance athletes due to high vagal tone.
Opposite of tachycardia; refers to low resting HR.
A heart rate condition defined relative to clinical context and symptoms.
Large airways branching from the trachea into each lung.
Conduct air toward smaller branches and bronchioles.
Cartilage-supported air passages for ventilation.
Main airway conduits distributing airflow into lungs.
Small airway branch of bronchi leading toward alveolar regions.
Regulates airflow via smooth muscle tone (bronchoconstriction/dilation).
Conducting airways that lack cartilage compared with larger bronchi.
Pathway leading to alveolar ducts and alveoli.
Smallest blood vessel where exchange with tissues occurs.
Site of gas, nutrient, and waste diffusion between blood and cells.
Thin-walled vessels forming networks within organs.
Exchange vessels connecting arterioles to venules.
Joints where bones are connected by cartilage with limited movement.
Examples include intervertebral discs and pubic symphysis.
Provide stability with small degrees of motion and shock absorption.
Joint type defined by cartilage connection rather than synovial cavity.
Myosin head attachment to actin during contraction.
Force-generating link between thick and thin filaments.
Temporary bond that cycles using ATP during contraction.
Mechanical connection responsible for tension development.
Membrane potential becomes less negative (toward positive).
Electrical change that can initiate an action potential.
Often driven by Na+ influx in excitable membranes.
First phase of an action potential before repolarization.
Relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle when chambers fill with blood.
Period when ventricular pressure decreases and filling occurs.
Opposite of systole; associated with filling rather than ejection.
Time when semilunar valves are closed and AV valves typically open.
Passive movement from higher to lower concentration or partial pressure.
Transport driven by random molecular motion without energy input.
Mechanism for O2/CO2 exchange across membranes.
Net movement down a gradient until equilibrium is approached.
Farther from the trunk or point of attachment.
Direction term opposite of proximal.
Example: the hand is distal to the elbow.
Used to describe limb locations relative to the body.
Surface recording of the heart’s electrical activity over time.
Graphical tracing of depolarization and repolarization events.
Clinical tool showing waves/complexes like P, QRS, and T.
Noninvasive measure of cardiac electrical conduction patterns.
Connective tissue sheath surrounding each individual muscle fiber.
Layer that supports fibers and helps transmit force laterally.
Fine CT wrapping around myocytes within a fascicle.
Innermost muscle connective tissue layer.
Dense connective tissue surrounding an entire muscle.
Outermost CT layer that merges with fascia and tendon.
Protective sheath that helps transmit force to tendons.
Whole-muscle connective tissue envelope.
Force-producing skeletal muscle fibers outside the muscle spindle.
Typical muscle fibers responsible for generating movement and tension.
Innervated by alpha motor neurons (contrast with intrafusal fibers).
Main contractile fibers of skeletal muscle.
Bundles of muscle fibers within a muscle.
Groups of fibers wrapped by perimysium.
Structural organization level between fiber and whole muscle.
Muscle compartments that contribute to force transmission.
Muscle fiber type that contracts rapidly and produces high power.
Typically fatigues faster than slow-twitch fibers.
Often associated with higher glycolytic capacity (Type IIa/IIx).
Fiber type recruited more for high-intensity or explosive tasks.
Joints connected by dense fibrous connective tissue.
Allow little to no movement (e.g., skull sutures).
Joint type defined by collagenous connection rather than synovial cavity.
Stable joints optimized for protection rather than mobility.
Tendon proprioceptor that senses tension/force in the musculotendinous unit.
Receptor that can inhibit muscle activation when tension is excessive.
Protective feedback sensor located near the tendon–muscle junction.
Proprioceptor that responds primarily to muscle tension rather than length.
Oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells.
Binds O2 in the lungs and helps deliver it to tissues.
Protein that also contributes to CO2 transport and buffering.
Key molecule determining blood’s oxygen-carrying capacity.
Smooth cartilage covering articular surfaces to reduce friction.
Glassy cartilage found in joints and structures like the trachea.
Tissue that supports and cushions while allowing smooth movement.
Type of cartilage important for joint function and airway support.
Central part of the A-band containing only thick (myosin) filaments.
Sarcomere region with no actin overlap (at rest).
Area around the M-line where only myosin is present.
Zone that narrows/disappears as overlap increases during contraction.
Light sarcomere band containing thin (actin) filaments only.
Region that shortens during contraction as filaments slide.
Band spanning the Z-line with actin but no myosin presence.
Sarcomere area whose length changes with muscle shortening.
Below or toward the feet in anatomical position.
Directional term opposite of superior.
Example: the stomach is inferior to the heart.
Anatomical descriptor for lower body position.
Specialized fibers within muscle spindles that detect stretch/length changes.
Sensory-related fibers that adjust spindle sensitivity (not primary force producers).
Fibers innervated by gamma motor neurons to tune the spindle response.
Muscle spindle components involved in proprioceptive feedback.
Ventricular conduction pathway carrying impulses down the left septum.
Branch of the AV bundle leading to Purkinje network in the left ventricle.
Part of the conduction system coordinating left ventricular depolarization.
Electrical pathway supporting synchronized ventricular contraction.
Left AV valve between left atrium and left ventricle.
Prevents backflow from the left ventricle into the left atrium during systole.
AV valve that opens during diastole to fill the left ventricle.
Two-cusped valve controlling left-sided inflow.
Neuron that sends signals from the CNS to muscle fibers to cause contraction.
Efferent nerve cell that activates skeletal muscle.
Cell whose axon forms neuromuscular junctions with muscle fibers.
Neural output pathway driving voluntary movement.
A motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it innervates.
Functional unit of force production controlled by recruitment.
Smaller motor units allow finer control; larger units produce more force.
Neuromuscular structure that determines graded muscle force.
Joints permitting movement in three planes.
Ball-and-socket joints like shoulder and hip.
Allow flex/extend, abduct/adduct, and rotate.
Highly mobile synovial joints with three degrees of freedom.
A single skeletal muscle cell, long and typically multinucleated.
Basic cellular unit of skeletal muscle tissue.
Cell containing myofibrils arranged in repeating sarcomeres.
Contractile cell enclosed by the sarcolemma.
Proprioceptor within muscle that senses stretch and rate of length change.
Receptor that initiates the stretch reflex to resist rapid lengthening.
Sensory organ containing intrafusal fibers aligned with extrafusal fibers.
Primary detector of muscle length for posture and movement control.
Middle muscular layer of the heart wall responsible for pumping.
Contractile cardiac muscle tissue generating ventricular and atrial force.
Heart muscle layer between endocardium and epicardium.
Muscle tissue that produces cardiac contractions.
Rod-like contractile structure in muscle fibers composed of sarcomeres.
Repeating chain of sarcomeres that produces muscle contraction.
Subcellular structure containing thick and thin myofilaments.
Primary contractile organelle inside a skeletal muscle fiber.
Contractile protein filament within myofibrils (actin or myosin).
Thin (actin) and thick (myosin) filaments that create force through sliding.
Protein strands that form sarcomere structure and function.
Filaments responsible for contraction mechanics in striated muscle.
Primary protein of thick filaments in muscle.
Molecular motor whose heads bind actin and hydrolyze ATP to generate force.
Thick filament protein responsible for crossbridge cycling.
Contractile protein whose power stroke pulls actin during contraction.
Synapse where a motor neuron communicates with a skeletal muscle fiber.
Site where acetylcholine is released to excite the muscle membrane.
Connection converting nerve impulses into muscle fiber depolarization.
Specialized junction between motor neuron terminal and sarcolemma.
Autonomic division associated with “rest-and-digest” functions.
Generally decreases heart rate and supports digestion and recovery.
System that promotes energy conservation and recovery states.
Counterbalances sympathetic activation by slowing physiological output.
Connective tissue surrounding a fascicle (bundle) of muscle fibers.
CT layer between endomysium and epimysium.
Provides a pathway for nerves and blood vessels within muscle.
Supports force transmission by organizing fibers into bundles.
Double-layered membrane surrounding lungs and lining thoracic cavity.
Visceral pleura covers lungs; parietal pleura lines chest wall.
Reduces friction during breathing and supports pressure coupling.
Membranous system creating a sealed pleural space for lung mechanics.
Pressure within the pleural cavity, usually negative relative to alveolar pressure.
Negative pressure that helps keep lungs expanded against the chest wall.
Pressure that changes with breathing to enable lung inflation/deflation.
Key pressure variable linking chest wall movement to lung volume change.
Force-producing step where myosin pivots and pulls actin.
Crossbridge event that generates tension and filament sliding.
Movement of the myosin head after phosphate release during cycling.
Mechanical action translating ATP energy into muscle force.
Sensory receptor providing information about body position and movement.
Receptor that senses muscle length, tension, or joint position.
Includes structures like muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs.
Feedback sensor essential for coordination, balance, and motor control.
Closer to the trunk or point of attachment.
Directional term opposite of distal.
Example: the elbow is proximal to the wrist.
Used to describe relative locations along a limb.
Semilunar valve between the right ventricle and pulmonary artery.
Prevents backflow into the right ventricle after ejection.
Opens during right ventricular systole to allow pulmonary flow.
Valve ensuring one-way blood movement toward the lungs.
Specialized conduction fibers that rapidly distribute impulses through ventricles.
Network that coordinates synchronized ventricular contraction.
Terminal conduction system delivering depolarization to ventricular myocardium.
Fast-conducting fibers downstream of bundle branches.
ECG wave representing atrial depolarization.
Electrical event corresponding to atrial activation before contraction.
Surface ECG deflection produced by atrial electrical activity.
Cardiac tracing component that precedes the QRS complex.
ECG complex representing ventricular depolarization.
Electrical event associated with ventricular activation and contraction onset.
Atrial repolarization is typically hidden within this complex.
Major ECG deflection produced by ventricular electrical activity.
Blood cell specialized for oxygen transport using hemoglobin.
Cell that carries O2 from lungs to tissues and assists CO2 transport.
Anucleate cell optimized for gas exchange and deformability in capillaries.
Primary cellular component determining oxygen-carrying capacity of blood.
Return of membrane potential toward resting level after depolarization.
Electrical recovery phase following an action potential.
Often driven by K+ efflux in excitable membranes.
Process restoring resting polarity after excitation.
Ventricular conduction pathway carrying impulses down the right septum.
Branch of the AV bundle that activates right ventricular Purkinje fibers.
Part of the conduction system coordinating right ventricular depolarization.
Electrical pathway supporting synchronized ventricular contraction.
Cell membrane of a muscle fiber.
Excitable membrane that conducts action potentials along the muscle cell.
Membrane enclosing the sarcoplasm and associated structures.
Muscle cell plasma membrane that communicates electrical signals.
Basic contractile unit of striated muscle.
Region between Z-lines containing repeating actin–myosin arrangement.
Smallest functional unit capable of contraction in skeletal muscle.
Structure whose shortening underlies muscle contraction.
Cytoplasm of a muscle fiber.
Intracellular fluid containing organelles, enzymes, and substrates.
Muscle cell interior surrounding myofibrils.
Cellular matrix where metabolic processes occur in the myofiber.
Specialized smooth ER in muscle that stores and releases calcium.
Calcium reservoir that enables excitation–contraction coupling.
Network surrounding myofibrils controlling intracellular Ca2+ levels.
Structure that releases Ca2+ to start contraction and re-sequesters it for relaxation.
Valves at ventricular outflow (aortic and pulmonary) preventing backflow into ventricles.
Open during systole to allow ejection; close during diastole to prevent regurgitation.
Heart valves located between ventricles and great arteries.
Ensure one-way flow from ventricles into aorta and pulmonary artery.
Primary pacemaker of the heart initiating the electrical impulse.
Conduction structure that sets resting heart rhythm.
Node in the right atrium that triggers atrial depolarization.
Source of spontaneous depolarizations governing heart rate.
Muscle shortens because actin slides past myosin via crossbridge cycling.
Model explaining contraction without filaments themselves shortening.
Sarcomere shortening occurs from increased filament overlap.
Theory linking ATP-driven myosin cycling to mechanical shortening.
Muscle fiber type specialized for endurance and aerobic metabolism.
Fatigue-resistant fiber with high oxidative capacity.
Typically recruited early for low-to-moderate intensity activity.
Fiber type suited for posture and prolonged submaximal work.
Above or toward the head in anatomical position.
Directional term opposite of inferior.
Example: the heart is superior to the stomach.
Anatomical descriptor for higher body position.
Autonomic division supporting “fight-or-flight” responses.
Generally increases heart rate, contractility, and blood pressure.
System that mobilizes energy and elevates arousal for stress/exertion.
Counterbalances parasympathetic activity by increasing physiological output.
Lubricating fluid inside synovial joints that reduces friction.
Fluid that nourishes and cushions articular cartilage.
Joint lubricant produced by synovial membrane.
Viscous fluid enabling smooth, low-friction joint movement.
Freely movable joints with a capsule, synovial membrane, and synovial fluid.
Joint type enabling the greatest range of motion (e.g., knee, shoulder).
Articulations with a joint cavity and articular cartilage.
Movement-focused joints defined by enclosed synovial space.
Contraction phase of the cardiac cycle when blood is pumped out.
Often refers specifically to ventricular contraction/ejection.
Period when ventricular pressure rises and semilunar valves open.
Opposite of diastole; associated with ejection rather than filling.
Faster-than-normal heart rate (often >100 bpm in adults, context dependent).
Opposite of bradycardia; refers to elevated HR relative to baseline.
May occur from exercise, stress, stimulants, or pathology depending on context.
A heart rate condition defined relative to clinical situation and symptoms.
Dense connective tissue attaching muscle to bone.
Structure transmitting muscle force to the skeleton to create movement.
Collagen-rich tissue with high tensile strength.
Connective link between contractile tissue and bone leverage.
Sustained muscle contraction from high-frequency stimulation.
Condition where twitches summate with incomplete relaxation.
Physiology term distinct from the infectious disease tetanus.
Force plateau resulting from rapid repeated motor neuron firing.
Airway conducting air from larynx to bronchi.
Cartilage-reinforced tube that maintains an open airway.
Primary conducting airway before branching into the lungs.
Structure that routes inhaled air toward pulmonary passages.
Right AV valve between right atrium and right ventricle.
Prevents backflow into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
Opens during diastole to fill the right ventricle.
Three-cusped valve controlling right-sided inflow.
Regulatory protein that blocks myosin-binding sites on actin at rest.
Filament that shifts position when troponin binds calcium.
Actin-associated protein controlling access for crossbridge formation.
Protein that helps regulate contraction by masking/unmasking binding sites.
Calcium-binding regulatory protein complex on the thin filament.
Protein that moves tropomyosin to expose myosin-binding sites on actin.
Key switch for contraction initiation when Ca2+ binds.
Thin filament regulator enabling crossbridge formation during excitation.
Invagination of the sarcolemma that carries action potentials into the fiber.
Structure enabling rapid excitation of deep myofibrils.
Membrane tubule that couples electrical signals to SR calcium release.
Pathway for synchronized contraction across the muscle fiber.
ECG wave representing ventricular repolarization.
Electrical recovery event of ventricles after depolarization.
ECG deflection following the QRS complex.
Surface tracing component reflecting ventricular electrical reset.
Single brief contraction-relaxation response to one stimulus.
Mechanical response of a muscle fiber to one action potential.
Basic unit of muscular response that can summate into tetanus.
One-cycle contraction event whose force depends on fiber type and conditions.
Slow, oxidative muscle fiber with high fatigue resistance.
Fiber specialized for endurance and aerobic metabolism.
Typically recruited first for low-intensity and postural tasks.
Muscle fiber with high mitochondrial and capillary density (relative).
Fast-twitch fiber with mixed oxidative and glycolytic capacity.
Intermediate fatigue resistance with strong power output.
Often recruited for moderate-to-high intensity efforts requiring speed and endurance.
Fast fiber type bridging Type I endurance and Type IIx explosiveness.
Fast-twitch fiber with high glycolytic capacity and very high power potential.
Fatigues quickly compared with Type I and Type IIa fibers.
Fiber type recruited for maximal or near-maximal explosive actions.
High-velocity, high-force fiber specialized for short-duration output.
Joints permitting movement primarily in one plane.
Examples include hinge (elbow/knee) and pivot (atlas-axis).
Allow one primary degree of freedom (e.g., flexion/extension).
Synovial joints designed for single-axis motion.
Blood vessel carrying blood toward the heart.
Typically carries deoxygenated blood (except pulmonary veins).
Lower-pressure vessel often containing valves to prevent backflow.
Returns blood from tissues to the heart via venous pathways.
Vessels returning blood to the heart (venules to veins).
Low-pressure return network often aided by muscle pump and valves.
Circulatory system component responsible for venous return.
Pathway collecting blood from capillaries and delivering it back to the heart.
Lower heart chamber that pumps blood out of the heart.
Right ventricle pumps to lungs; left ventricle pumps to systemic circulation.
Primary pressure-generating chambers of the heart.
Chambers that eject blood through semilunar valves.
Small vessel that drains capillary beds and leads into veins.
Collects blood leaving capillaries and begins venous return.
Low-pressure vessel connecting capillaries to larger veins.
Initial segment of the venous system after capillaries.
Series of vertebrae forming the spine.
Supports the trunk and protects the spinal cord.
Central axial structure enabling posture and movement.
Skeletal column providing structural support and neural protection.
Boundary of a sarcomere; anchors thin (actin) filaments.
Line defining sarcomere length from Z-line to Z-line.
Structural region where actin and supporting proteins attach.
Sarcomere landmark that moves closer during contraction as the sarcomere shortens.
